Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
Description suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency was not communicating appropriately with other involved
agencies regarding safety matters involving a foster youth. A
foster youth was placed in an unsafe placement by the agency.
The agency failed to utilize policy and relies on other agencies to
guide them.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on September 23,
2024. There was no additional information.
DHHS POS Foster Care (FC) Supervisor was interviewed via
telephone on September 23, 2024. Youth A was court ordered to
Biological Father’s care in March 2024. There is a termination
petition pending for Youth A’s Mother. Since returning to Biological
Father’s care there have been two Department of Health and
Human Services (DHHS) investigations due to concerns of
physical abuse. There is a history of physical abuse allegations
regarding Biological Father. On 8/22/2024 a complaint came in
regarding physical abuse of Youth A by Biological Father.
DHHS POS FC Supervisor stated she received a phone call from
the Private Agency Foster Care (PAFC) because they were at the
hospital with Youth A and were confused by what their role was as
far as safety planning. She stated she initially spoke with Director
and then Program Manager. She stated the agency felt they
weren’t getting the support they needed in order to safety plan.
She advised to have a discussion with Biological Father to see if
he would agree to allow Youth A to stay with a relative for the
duration of the investigation. She stated the agency was confused
because they didn’t feel they should be discussing the allegations
with Biological Father and didn’t know how to safety plan without
providing that information. DHHS POS FC Supervisor clarified
Youth A had visible bruises on different areas of his body. She
advised Program Manager they had the ability to file a petition if
Biological Father did not agree to the safety plan and there were
immediate concerns with returning Youth A to the household.
2

DHHS POS FC Supervisor stated she assisted the PAFC on
8/22/2024 via phone when the new complaint came through by
providing the previously mentioned advice on how to move
forward to Director and Program Manager. On 8/23/2024 she sent
a follow up email to inquire how Youth A was doing and how it
went with the safety plan and there was no response. She knew
they had been in contact with DHHS Worker and assumed there
was a safety plan in place and the investigation was moving
forward. She didn’t hear from the PAFC until they sent an email
regarding the court hearing where Biological Father was
dismissed as a respondent. DHHS POS FC Supervisor stated
every time there is a difficult decision to make, the PAFC struggles
with simple case planning tasks. It’s been an issue with this
particular case from the beginning.
DHHS POS FC Supervisor stated the PAFC sent an email to
DHHS Worker to advise a court hearing was held earlier that day
and Biological Father had been dismissed from the petition. There
was concern due to the ongoing DHHS investigation regarding
physical abuse. PAFC was asked via email if court was aware of
the DHHS investigation and ongoing concerns and was told by
Foster Care Worker (FCW) that the court didn’t ask so it wasn’t
addressed in court DHHS POS FC Supervisor advised the PAFC
it was their responsibility to notify the court of Youth A’s progress
and safety and this should have been addressed during the
hearing. It was also learned when the agency sent an email to
DHHS worker that Biological Father never agreed to a safety plan
where Youth A was out of the house. The safety plan that was
implemented was Biological Father would refrain from physical
discipline. Safety plan included Biological Father locking his doors
at night due to reported sleepwalking and some of the physical
abuse occurring while Biological Father was sleepwalking.
DHHS POS FC Supervisor stated there was a meeting held
recently to discuss the DHHS investigation and it was determined
DHHS would be substantiating Biological Father for physical
abuse of Youth A. DHHS assisted the PAFC by having a
conversation with Biological Father regarding an investigation
update and Youth A is now safety planned out of the home.
DHHS Worker was interviewed via telephone on October 2,
2024. She stated FCW is a new worker and is trying her best but
does lack experience. She stated Biological Father is going to be
substantiated for physical abuse of Youth A and they are working
on filing a petition against Biological Father since he was recently
3

dismissed as a respondent on the active foster care case. She
stated the agency was in communication with DHHS, but DHHS
does not give dispositional findings ahead of time. She clarified
based on the bruising on Youth A, there was concern by all
involved regarding his safety in Biological Father’s care. DHHS
Worker stated there were miscommunications on all levels of this
case, specifically DHHS and PAFC. DHHS Worker also stated
FCW always responded when she reached out and asked for
anything.
When this complaint was first assigned, the PAFC did follow
through with taking Youth A for a medical assessment and safety
planning. She stated the agency did struggle somewhat with the
safety plan and knowing what to do, but acknowledged there was
some miscommunication on all parts. She stated PAFC was
aware of the concerns from the beginning. Despite knowing the
concerns, the agency participated in a court hearing regarding
Youth A and did not disclose the current concerns and
investigation to the court prior to Biological Father being dismissed
as a respondent.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
October 4, 2024. She stated she is a new worker and has been
assigned to Youth A’s case since the end of July, 2024. She
stated she completed new worker training two weeks ago. FCW
stated she was contacted by DHHS Worker regarding a new
investigation involving concerns Youth A had been physically
abused by Biological Father, who he is placed with. She stated
she and Program Manager (PM) were in the Detroit area and
made to face-to-face contact with Youth A along with the DHHS
Worker after being notified of the new complaint. Youth A was
observed and had noticeable bruises on his body at the time face-
to-face contact was made at a relative’s home. She clarified a
relative watches Youth A while Biological Father is at work.
During the face-to-face meeting FCW and PM spoke to Youth A.
FCW stated PM did the majority of the talking since she is a new
worker. They took Youth A to the hospital and the social worker
and multiple doctors agreed that Youth A should not return home
due to the concerns of physical abuse. FCW and PM weren’t sure
how that would work. They spoke with DHHS Worker and inquired
what they should do from there. FCW stated she and PM recall
DHHS Worker stating that if Biological Father refused to allow
Youth A to go somewhere else for the time being they can’t move
him. However, during a follow up meeting, DHHS Worker stated
she didn’t say that, and they could have filed a petition based on
4

the concerns. FCW stated they followed the guidance they were
given but during a later meeting with DHHS POS FC Supervisor
and DHHS Worker, there were different statements made.
DHHS Worker provided a summary of actions that needed to
occur. She advised FCW and PM to take Youth A to the hospital
to be checked due to the bruising. FCW stated there was
confusion since that is something that a DHHS worker would
typically do. FCW and PM both spoke with Biological Father
regarding a safety plan. They attempted to safety plan to have
Youth A stay elsewhere, however Biological Father was upset and
repeatedly stated he didn’t have anywhere for Youth A to go, and
the bruises could have come from other individuals. FCW stated
she and PM were under the impression that since Biological
Father refused to allow Youth A to stay somewhere else, there
wasn’t anything else they could do. The agency then modified the
safety plan to include Biological Father and Youth A locking their
bedroom doors at night since Biological Father indicated he
sleepwalks and when he does that, he hits Youth A. A few days
later, DHHS Worker contacted FCW, and she was told about
Biological Father refusing to follow the safety plan and there was
no mention of an emergency petition. DHHS Worker requested
the agency work on an improved safety plan that included not to
use physical discipline which Biological Father ended up agreeing
to and signing.
FCW did not realize she needed to provide an update to the court
regarding the allegations. She was under the impression she only
testifies to home visits she completed. At court, FCW testified to
her contact with Youth A and Biological Father regarding her
interactions at home visits. After the court hearing, DHHS Worker
emailed her and asked if the court was made aware of the recent
concerns. FCW and her coworkers were under the impression that
DHHS would bring up concerns regarding their involvement. The
court hearing occurred via Zoom and PM sat next to her but did
not speak up to notify the court. FCW stated she did not notify the
court or any of the attorneys involved that DHHS was involved due
to concerns of physical abuse. She was told to write a court report
and provide Parent Agency Treatment Plan’s (PATP’s). She
wasn’t aware she needed to update everyone as much as
possible prior to court. A video call was held after court to
determine if there were any course of action the PAFC could take
to notify the court regarding the concern and “undo” the motion
and was told that was not possible. FCW stated if she had known
she needed to provide all of the information she would have.
5

Program Manager (PM) was interviewed via telephone on
October 4, 2024. She clarified her position is Program Manager,
however she is acting as the FC supervisor on this case since she
previous experience with the case as a licensing supervisor and
FC supervisor. She became aware of the DHHS investigation
involving concerns of physical abuse of Youth A by Biological
Father on 8/22/24. She stated the experience with DHHS on this
investigation was different from her experience with other DHHS
investigations in the past and there was some confusion. In this
situation the DHHS worker asked the PAFC to safe plan based on
the allegations she was investigating as opposed to the DHHS
worker doing the safety plan. She isn’t aware of the DHHS worker
doing a safety plan on her own until just recently. PM clarified
there have been 4 safety plans since the investigation started.
DHHS Worker told them to safety plan and PM inquired if there
was anything specific to include in the plan and she said the
agency can choose what to include in the safety plan. They asked
what to do if Biological Father doesn’t agree to out of home
placement and DHHS Worker said they can’t force him to agree to
that safety plan and if this occurs, she should talk to PAFC’s upper
management
FCW and PM arrived at the relative home where Youth A was
located and DHHS Worker joined roughly 30 minutes later. Upon
arriving, DHHS Worker asked them to take Youth A for a medical
evaluation. They took him to a Children’s Hospital in Detroit.
Biological Father would not agree to out of home placement.
Biological Father had reported the bruising occurred when he was
sleepwalking, therefore the safety plan included Youth A not
falling asleep in Biological Father’s room. The plan also included
to have Biological Father lock his bedroom door so Youth A
couldn’t get in. Agency sent the safety plan to DHHS Worker, and
she asked them to also include no physical discipline, so they did
an addendum to the initial safety plan.
PM stated FCW is a new worker and recently completed CWTI
within the last 2 weeks. PM stated they had not received direction
from DHHS regarding the investigation, therefore she did not
instruct FCW to discuss the physical abuse concerns during the
recent court hearing on 9/16/2024. She stated she isn’t familiar
with DHHS investigations that involve biological parents and
acknowledged she could have done a better job preparing FCW
for the court hearing and what information should have been
shared. She also stated the communication during the DHHS
investigation could have been better. The PAFC was on the
6

property, but they were not present when DHHS Worker
interviewed Youth A so they were not aware of what information
was disclosed at that time and were only provided a brief
summary of Youth A’s disclosure after the meeting.
Documents reviewed:
• 9/16/2024 court order states Biological Father is released
from the case.
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case file. Reviewed social work
contacts between 8/22/2024-10/7/2024.
• 8/22/2024 social work contacts: Multiple bruises viewed on
Youth A’s body. Youth A was taken for a medical
evaluation and a safety plan was developed after speaking
with DHHS worker. PAFC contacted DHHS POS FC
Supervisor and expressed uncertainty on how to proceed
as DHHS Worker was not offering assistance regarding the
safety plan.
• 8/23/2024 social work contact: DHHS POS FC Supervisor
sent email to PAFC regarding status of Youth A. No
response received.
• 9/3/2024 social work contact: PAFC spoke with DHHS
Worker regarding updated safety plan for Youth A to
include no physical discipline.
• 9/19/2024 social work contact: FCW sent an email to
DHHS Worker and DHHS POS FC Supervisor informing
them court jurisdiction closed on Biological Father. Concern
expressed regarding the court case closure regarding
Biological Father and current concerns of physical abuse.
Questions as to whether or not court was made aware of
concerns and FCW indicated it was not brought up or
discussed during the court hearing.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance. During interviews
conducted there is acknowledgement that communication could
have been better between DHHS Worker and PAFC, however,
given FCW is very new to child welfare there should have been
clear direction from experienced supervision to instruct her to
provide the court with an accurate update regarding concerns of
physical abuse of Youth A by Biological Father. PAFC did not
make the court aware of the concerns despite being actively
involved and court jurisdiction was terminated on Biological
Father, impacting the safety needs of Youth A. A new petition has
been filed on Biological Father as a result of being substantiated
for physical abuse of Youth A and Youth A has been removed
from Biological Father’s care.
Conclusion Violation Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
